str2: Paul, Paulus. Of Latin origin; Paulus, the name of a Roman and of an apostle.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: Answer, bid, bring word, command. A primary verb; to speak or say.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Active - 1st Person Singular
str2: I am, exist. The first person singular present indicative; a prolonged form of a primary and defective verb; I exist.

parse: Verb - Perfect Participle Active - Nominative Masculine Singular
str2: A prolonged form of a primary stao stah'-o; to stand, used in various applications.
On, to, against, on the basis of, at.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
From the base of basis; a step, i.e. Foot-breath; by implication, a rostrum, i.e. A tribunal.
Of Latin origin; Caesar, a title of the Roman emperor.
Where, whither, when, in what place. Genitive case of hos as adverb; at which place, i.e. Where.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Accusative 1st Person Singular
str2: I, the first-person pronoun. A primary pronoun of the first person I.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: Third person singular active present of deo; also deon deh-on'; neuter active participle of the same; both used impersonally; it is Necessary.

parse: Verb - Present Infinitive Middle or Passive
str2: Properly, to distinguish, i.e. Decide; by implication, to try, condemn, punish.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Active - 1st Person Singular
str2: To act unjustly towards, injure, harm. From adikos; to be unjust, i.e. do wrong.
Jewish. From Iouda; Judaean, i.e. Belonging to Jehudah.
Probably adverb of comparative from hos; which how, i.e. In that manner.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Nominative 2nd Person Singular
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Active - 2nd Person Singular
str2: From epi and ginosko; to know upon some mark, i.e. Recognize; by implication, to become fully acquainted with, to acknowledge.
Very well. Neuter of the comparative of kalos; better than many.
